metadata.case_name: Sankatha Singh and others v. State

facts.text: Appellants convicted by Magistrate, I Class, Gyanpur, of offences under ss. 452 and 323 read with s.34, I.P.C. Kharpattu, one of the appellants, also convicted of an offence under s. 324, I.P.C.
Appellants appealed against their conviction to Sessions Judge, Gyanpur.
Appeal fixed for hearing on November 30, 1956. Neither appellants nor their counsel appeared.
Sessions Judge (Sri Tej Pal Singh) dismissed the appeal on merits after perusing Magistrate's judgment and record, stating 'I find no ground for any interference.'
On December 17, 1956, appellants filed application for restoration, explaining absence due to ekka overturning on way to court causing injuries.

On July 2, 1957, Sri Tej Pal Singh allowed restoration application, citing sufficient cause, requirements of s.423 CrPC for hearing appellant/pleader/PP, no notice u/s 422, judgment not complying with s.367, and need for re-hearing in ends of justice.
Sri Tripathi, successor Sessions Judge, held order dated July 2, 1957 ultra vires and without jurisdiction, as no power to review or restore dismissed appeal.
Appellants filed revision in Allahabad High Court (Criminal Revision No. 1299 of 1957), which dismissed it on March 19, 1959, agreeing with Sri Tripathi.
Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether Sri Tej Pal Singh could set aside his first order dated November 30, 1956, dismissing the appeal for non-appearance, and order re-hearing of the appeal.

petitioner_arguments.text: Sufficient cause for non-appearance due to ekka overturning causing injuries.
No notice issued to appellants as required by s.422 CrPC.
Judgment of November 30, 1956 did not comply with s.367 CrPC as it lacked salient points.
s.423 CrPC enjoins appellate court to dispose of appeal on merits after hearing appellant or pleader and Public Prosecutor.
Sessions Judge could order re-hearing using inherent powers to further ends of justice.
Sri Tripathi not justified in sitting in judgment over order of predecessor passed within jurisdiction.
Sessions Judge had jurisdiction to dispose of restoration application.

respondent_arguments.text: Appellate court has no power to review or restore appeal once disposed of.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.369 CrPC read with s.424 CrPC

respondent_arguments.text: Appeal was dismissed on merits, not for default, after considering record.

court_reasoning.text: Criminal appeal cannot be dismissed for default of appellants or counsel; court must adjourn or consider on merits and pass final order.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sessions Judge did consider merits and found no ground for interference.

court_reasoning.text: Omission to write detailed judgment may violate s.367 but does not allow judge to set it aside himself.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.369 read with s.424 prohibits altering or reviewing signed judgment except clerical errors.

court_reasoning.text: s.423 allows disposal on merits if appellant or pleader does not appear (words 'if he appears' qualify hearing requirement).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Notice u/s 422 to appellant or pleader sufficient; practice is notice to counsel.

court_reasoning.text: Inherent powers cannot override specific prohibition in s.369 CrPC.
Successor judge competent to consider validity when objection raised.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sri Tripathi rightly held order ultra vires.

court_reasoning.text: Jurisdiction to dispose application does not include power to review prohibited by s.369.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No jurisdiction to set aside dismissal order.

holdings.text: Sessions Judge could not set aside his dismissal order and order re-hearing.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Offences for which appellants were convicted by Magistrate

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Governing appellate procedure, judgment requirements, notice, hearing, and prohibition on review

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, holding that the Sessions Judge had no power to review or set aside his earlier dismissal order and order re-hearing, affirming the High Court and Sessions Judge Sri Tripathi.

key_quotes.text: A criminal appeal cannot be dismissed for the default of the appellants or their counsel. The Court has either to adjourn the hearing of the appeal to enable them to appear, or should consider the appeal on merits and pass the final order.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core principle on handling non-appearance in criminal appeals

key_quotes.text: Section 369, read with s. 424, of the Code, makes it clear that the appellate Court is not to alter or review the judgment once signed, except for the purpose of correcting a clerical error.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Inherent powers cannot be exercised to do what the Code specifically prohibits the Court from doing.
key_quotes.speaker: court
